HOUSING AND DEVELOPMENT (AMENDMENT) BILL


    Order for Second Reading read.

     The Minister for National Development (Mr Teh Cheang Wan): Mr Speaker, Sir, I beg to move, "That the Bill be now read a Second time."

    Under existing mortgages issued by the Housing and Development Board, the Board can revise the interest rate upon giving three months' notice in writing to be served by registered post. The Government decided in February 1986 to peg the HDB's mortgage interest rate at 0.1% above the CPF rate, which is reviewed six-monthly to reflect market rates of interest. This makes it necessary for HDB to have the facility to vary its mortgage rate quickly. Lessees can then enjoy earlier the benefits of lower rates, if the CPF rate is lowered, as had happened in the last two revisions. One month's notice to the mortgagors by ordinary post is required for this purpose. The proposed amendment in clasue 3 of the Bill is intended to facilitate this.

    At present, if there is a revision in the rent or maintenance fees of the Board's rental properties, the tenants affected are required to call at Area Offices to sign new or supplementary agreements. This process is cumbersome and time consuming. The proposed amendment in clause 5 will simplify administrative procedures and reduce inconvenience to the tenants as it enables the Board to effect such changes by a notification in the Gazette. The Board will also give publicity in the media to any such revision.

    Under clause 9 of the Bill, the Board has the power to acquire any HDB dwelling where the owner thereof, his spouse or any authorized occupier above the age of 14 years, has been convicted of the offence of throwing "killer litter" from any HDB property. Any application for HDB flats involving the offenders may also be cancelled. I would like to emphasize that the Board will only take action to acquire a flat after it is fully satisfied that the offender poses a serious and continuous threat or danger to other residents and

Column: 324

passers-by. The Board will consider each case carefully before taking action. An example would include a drunkard or an alcoholic who is prone to throwing heavy objects or other "killer litter" indiscriminately and repeatedly out of his HDB flat, thus endangering the lives of other people living below. The Board, in managing 600,000 properties, housing 85% of the population, has an obligation to make its housing estates a safe and secure environment to live in. It will fail in its duty if it allows people who throw killer litter to continue to stay in its estates and pose a threat to the lives of other residents.

    The Government also takes a serious view of HDB lessees who abuse the privileges of public housing by harbouring illegal immigrants. Their flats may be acquired and applications for HDB flats involving the offenders may be cancelled. Here again, I should explain that such a provision will not be invoked lightly. The Board will only invoke it after very serious and careful evaluation of the case at hand, and after giving due consideration to mitigating circumstances.

    There is provision for any person, who is aggrieved by a decision of the Board to acquire his flat, to appeal to me as the Minister in charge. The Board must satisfy me that its proposed action is fully justified before compulsory acquisition can take place. I am also advised that if the Board's final action in such a case is seen to be manifestly unjust, the aggrieved party can still take the matter to court.

    There are also other amendments to the Act to enable the HDB to perform its functions more efficiently and effectively, and to enable ex-JTC flats to be administered along similar lines as HDB flats. These are highlighted in the Explanatory Statement to the Bill.

    Sir, I beg to move.

    Question proposed.

     Dr Toh Chin Chye (Rochore): Mr Speaker, Sir, I wish to speak on clause 9(e), paragraphs (m) and (n) of the Bill. The clause relates to acquisition of the flat for offences as spelt out in the Penal Code. The sections are 304A, 336, 337 and 338. Section 304A is a list of punishments

Column: 325

relating to an act that causes death through rashness or negligence. Section 336 relates to punishments for an act which endangers life or the personal safety of others. Section 337 relates to causing hurt by an act which endangers life or the personal safety of others, and section 338 spells out the punishment for causing grievous hurt by an act which endangers life or the personal safety of others. These sections under the Penal Code spell out the amount of punishment that should be dealt out by a Judge.

    We are adding another type of punishment in addition to the punishments already spelt out under the Penal Code. We are now saying that the person, who is found guilty of contravening any of these sections, and his family will lose their property. We are compounding the punishment on offences which are deemed to be against the safety of a third person. However, if a tenant of an HDB flat were to be found convicted of murder, the family does not lose their flat. I do not see the logic at all. Here, a person who is aged 14 and above, if convicted under these sections of the Penal Code imperils the loss of property of the whole family even if the offence is minor compared to murder. In other words, for the act of a single person, you are punishing the whole family. The Police must first find the man who committed the offence, takes him to court, proves that he is the person who threw out the litter, whether it kills or does not kill. In fact, it is not culpable homicide. Assuming that he is found guilty, HDB says that all the members of the family will have to leave the flat. I do not see any equity at all in that.

    The punishment provided for in the Penal Code relates to terms of imprisonment. But there is no loss of property. If a person were to commit wilful murder, which is worse than any of these offences spelt out under these sections in the Penal Code, the family retains the flat. It is a ludicrous piece of legislation.

    Clause 9(e)(n) reads like this:

    'if the owner thereof, his spouse or any authorised occupier has been convicted of any offence under any

Column: 326

written law relating to immigration for giving food ... or stayed in Singapore in contravention of any written law relating to immigration ...' the family too loses their flat. Supposing I live in an HDB flat. I have a friend who is a foreigner but I would not know whether his immigration visa has expired or not. I take him to the hawker centre downstairs and give him food. Does that mean I am guilty under this Act? How do you go round about with such loose legislation? I can give him food in the common corridor.

    It is these loose pieces of legislation which have been coming up before Parliament that worry me. Take the Companies Act. The revised edition of the Companies Act appeared last year. I remember buying a copy last year. This year, in less than one year, we have got 72 amendments to the Act. Then you have the Securites Industry Act which has not yet been enforced. Hasty pieces of legislation, and this one is so loose - "for giving food." How? If I were living in Toa Payoh and I give him food in Jurong, I lose my flat. It does not make sense.

    There is already punishment under the Immigration Act for anybody who harbours an illegal immigrant. It is already provided for. Property is the essence of why the PAP has been successful in nation building because we have been telling them, "You have a share in Singapore." What is the share? The share is the piece of HDB flat that we have sold them and it is their property. It is not the HDB's property. The HDB, by empowering itself through so many acts, is acting as an enormous landlord. It is taking us back to feudalistic days when landlords were in charge of fiefs and the tenants living on the landlord's land would have to perform and behave according to the landlord's wishes. This is exactly what it is. We have already got under the Housing and Development Board Act a whole list under section 48A. There are three pages of how the Board can compulsorily acquire a flat. Now you are adding more today. I do not think this is a good piece of legislation. I do not believe that it has been properly thought out. The legislation is very loose - for giving food. What happens if I give him drinks?

    Another obnoxious thing is retroactive legislation. Once you accede to the principle

Column: 327

of retroactive legislation, it can be applied to any other Act. What was not punishable before can now become punishable through retroactive legislation. This should not be done. It worries me that this Bill will be retroactive to 1st March 1984, that is, 2(r) years ago. Can the Minister give us a good reason why it should be retroactive to 1st March 1984?

    I do not think, for good government, that the Government should make laws retroactive because you can apply this practice to any law, either to the Penal Code or to taxation. The danger is this: once we accede or concede to the principle of retroactive legislation, future governments (I am not talking just of this Government) will use that as a precedent. And you may well find you are caught on the principle that you are operating. This is dangerous. It should never be done. It is bad law.

    I am very concerned, of course, that the Government is efficient but I am more concerned that there must be equity, because government is by consensus. And unless people accept these pieces of law that are being presented in Parliament, I do not believe that you can enforce them. You cannot. So there has to be a certain amount of common sense in putting up a Bill. As I see it, that is missing.

    I do not concede to the principle of retroactive legislation nor do I believe that a person who throws out litter downstairs from his Housing Board flat should lose his property. You are evicting the whole family. Where are they going to? Under your argument any person who drives a car or who rides a motorcycle kills a pedestrian, which is not culpable homicide, should also lose his flat. It should really be so according to this Bill ? Because the whole idea is this: you are quoting here sections of the Penal Code where you do injury, not amounting to culpable homicide. If the Minister goes out of the National Development Building - of course, he has got a driver to drive his car, so he would not be worried about that - if by mischance, he should knock down a jaywalker, he comes under this Act. There is also the Traffic Ordinance. It just does not seem to me to make sense.

Column: 328



    I understand the purpose of this section. The purpose is a deterrent. Yes, you can govern through deterrents, condign punishment or through a carrot. This is no carrot at all. It is condign punishment, a threat. All governments operate in some way, subtly or openly, through some form of threat or punishment. For a whole family to lose their property just because of the act of one is unjust. It is similar to what happened during the days of the Emergency in Malaya when whole villages were resettled because a few were deemed to have collaborated with the Malayan Communist Party. It is exactly the same principle. It is a threat mounted on families, not on individuals.

    So I would like to put this before the Minister: that these sections which I have mentioned, paragraphs (m) and (n), should be carefully deliberated. I find it hard to support this Bill as long as paragraphs (m) and (n) are so loosely spelt out in this Bill. I do not believe and I do not subscribe to the loss of property just because someone has thrown litter.

     Dr Aline K. Wong (Changkat): Mr Speaker, Sir, I am concerned about the amendments which have to do with the solution or the management of the problem of killer litter. Not being a legal expert or even trained at all in law, I am not sure whether these amendments will not amount to punishing a culprit twice for the same crime. But I would leave this question to the legal experts. I am also concerned about the question of the law taking retroactive effect. But since the Member for Rochore has already raised this point, I do not wish to repeat it. Instead, I would like to add a further perspective to the question.

    No doubt HDB has to maintain its housing estates as a clean and safe environment for the residents. It can do so by eliciting the residents' cooperation, by carrying out public education, or at the same time it can also pass rules and regulations. No one in his right frame of mind would be against rules and regulations which help to contain problems created by uncaring and uncooperative residents. Sir, we are not talking about whether someone who has committed this offence of causing grave damage to

Column: 329

people's life and property should be punished. The Courts will take care of that. The Penal Code would have provided for that. The question is whether HDB should come in and evict the culprit, and not just the culprit but members of the family. And, as I read the law, not just members of the immediate family but anyone above the age of 14 residing with the family. I think the penalty, as contained in these amendments, is very very severe.

    First of all, most killer litter cases, as you read about them in the press, are committed by people who are engaged or involved in heated arguments, fights, quarrels, or perhaps as a result of drinking. In other words, the act which results in a death or maiming of another person, or causes serious damage to property, is not a premeditated act. And precisely because it is not premeditated, the law is not going to be an effective deterrent to people who might commit the same offence. Besides, people who live in high-rise flats, in private apartments, are as likely as people who live in HDB flats to throw out litter that could result in grave damage to people and property when they are in fits of anger or when they get drunk. So to me this is not a question of an abuse of the privilege of subsidized public housing, in the same way as if the flat is turned into a gambling den, a brothel, or some modern equivalent of an opium smoking joint.

    The severity of the penalty, I think, should also be viewed against the fact that outside of HDB housing, there is very little chance for the culprit and his family to be owning a home because, by definition, people who are eligible to apply for home ownership schemes under public housing cannot afford to have private housing. In other words, the severity of the penalty is depriving these people of home ownership when the HDB has the power to cancel an application where one member of the family or anybody listed on the application has been convicted of the offence and where the HDB has the power to evict the family or any person who stays with the family for having committed the offence.

Column: 330



    I think the Minister should really consider writing in a debarment period instead. Otherwise this is tantamount to depriving the family of owning a home for ever. A debarment period from applying should be a strong enough deterrent for people who do these things uncaringly or unthinkingly.

    To make members of the family responsible for the act committed by another individual or even one member of the family, to my mind, may not really square with the concept of individual rights and obligations under our present legal system. In ancient China, for example, we have read about how families and even entire clans could be punished for a very severe crime against the state. But these were instances of treason or rebellion. Are we talking about severe crimes so that the entire family should be punished? Are we trying to make our legal system into that kind of system? I think in our eagerness to stress the collective responsibility of families for the behaviour of their members, we should not go overboard and make members of the family responsible for the acts of individual members who, by definition in the amendments, are more or less adult people above the age of 14 years.

    We speak of common sense. To make parents responsible for the behaviour of children who are still under their custody probably makes common sense. But are we serious in believing that parents can be responsible for controlling the behaviour of grown-up people, people above the age of 14? And how much less can children be expected to influence the behaviour of their parents? Again, I do not see much common sense in making members of the family responsible for the act committed by any individual who now is residing with the family. This brings me to my last point.

    We could emphasize the collective responsibility of families towards each other. I think we should never stop emphasizing this point. If, in future, we were to introduce a law, hypothetically now of course, to make children support their parents, at least we will be making people do a good thing but even then, it is debatable whether we should compel people to do so. But in this amendment,

Column: 331

are we not penalizing members of the family for taking care of each other by staying together? I think there is some contradiction there.

    Mr Minister, you have the final say over cases of appeal, and just now you said that if people still do not agree with your decision, there is still a recourse to court, which is a good thing. I would urge you to be very careful in implementing the powers given to you by this Bill, or the Act if it is passed, because you have to take into consideration the circumstances surrounding the offence, the implications, the consequences for the family, as well as the legal and social implications of this law. You would not be put in an enviable position in having to make these decisions because you are not simply managing housing estates, you will become a moral arbitrator.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, I am sorry that I addressed a lot of my comments to the Minister and not to you.
11.30 am

     Mr S. Vasoo (Bo Wen): Mr Speaker, Sir, may I be allowed to comment on the Bill? I am concerned about further regulations of Housing Board matters. I feel that the Bill provides further discretionary power to the Housing Board itself and, as you know, further discretionary power would entail interpretations and implementations of these discretionary powers. This will obviously lead to problems and issues because it requires the Board officers to interpret and implement in terms of the rules and regulations which are enforced. I see that this would create further problems and create further strained relationship between residents and the HDB, in terms of how these new rules are going to be implemented.

    I feel that the whole objective of public housing is to build an identity around people. And if you are going to build ownership and a feeling of attachment and bondage to the homes and to the property, I view that Housing Board should direct itself more in terms of educating residents and to manage the environment more appropriately.

Column: 332



    Sir, more specifically, I am concerned about clause 4 (b) which empowers the HDB to prescribe a penalty for late payment of any rent, licence fees and maintenance fees. I can understand the rationale for this provision. But the definition is ill-defined in its sense. What does this penalty entail? Does it entail a surcharge? Does it entail a fine? Does it entail an interest levied? I find that nowhere in the Bill it is defined more clearly. And this would lead to some form of discretion in relation to what is going to be implemented. I feel that it needs to be specified. In order that we can be clear about how this is going to be implemented, I feel that the HDB has to try and work out more clearly in defining this aspect.

    I suggest that the Board itself also need to provide clear notification to families. As you know, some families, not that they do not want to pay their bills or their fees, sometimes I can see that under extenuating circumstances, they may forget to do this. I am of the opinion that adequate notice should be given to residents themselves.

    I feel that there are also genuine problems faced by residents to be able to meet the payment of fees. I think that under such circumstances, the Board should look at the specific problems and issues before imposing the penalty on such families.

    Sir, the other area which I am concerned and which has been shared by the Members for Changkat and Rochore is the powers which allow the Board to compulsorily acquire flats when killer litter offence has been committed. I see that the law is drastic in itself and it de-possesses families who may not necessarily be a party to the offence. And to punish such people and family members, I think it is really unnecessary and it creates further problems for them. Because I feel that having acquired the flat, they may have no place to go to because the Housing Board is trying to plan for homes for as many people as possible. I doubt that in future there will be places where such families can go to.

    Sir, this provision seems to be unfair because it punishes the family twice for an

Column: 333

offence which they have not committed. I feel that if this section has to be imposed it has to be directed at the person who commits the offence, so be it. The culprit has to be taken to task. He should be adequately punished and not the family. I feel that though the family, the aggrieved party, could appeal to the Board, I assess that the Board may need to set up a review committee, at least comprising community leaders, to ensure that there is equity, there is equitable justice, that is being applied to families that may be wrongfully deprived of their flat. I see that leaving it to HDB and the discretion of the officers raises some doubts and problems in the minds of the people who are affected. Sir, I feel that if the Board can set up a review committee comprising community leaders and Parliamentarians to review such cases, it will be useful. This is because the number of cases that are going to be convicted and deprived of flats will be small in number and such review committee would be able to help in deciding as to whether such families need to be de-possessed.

    With that note, I thank you, Sir.
11.37 am

     Dr Arthur Beng Kian Lam (Fengshan): Mr Speaker, Sir, I rise to seek clarification from the Minister regarding section 29 (2) which reads:

    'Notwithstanding anything contained in any tenancy or licence agreement or sale and purchase ....., the Board shall have the power to vary, with the approval of the Minister, the rent, licence fees or maintenance fees fixed under subsection (1).'

    Mr Speaker, Sir, I would like the Minister to clarify. Does this mean that, after tendering for a unit for rental, say, a shophouse, at any time the Minister can vary the rent, that he can change the rent at any time? Sir, I would also like to declare pecuniary interest in raising this point.

     Mr J.B. Jeyaretnam (Anson): Mr Speaker, Sir, before I begin to address myself to this Bill, I have a question to ask the Minister. I wrote to him on the 23rd of this month to ask if he would be good enough, when moving the Second

Column: 334

Reading of this Bill, to furnish the House with the number of persons, the total figure, who have been debarred from applying for HDB accommodation for one reason or another. I have not heard from the Minister in reply to this letter. I wonder whether the Minister is going to give us this information. Could you give it now, Mr Minister?

     Mr Teh Cheang Wan: Mr Speaker, Sir, the number of persons who have been debarred from applying for HDB flats due to the conviction of harbouring illegal immigrants is 23. There are 337 persons who have been debarred. They are either lessees or tenants who have assigned or sublet the whole of the flat without the approval of the Board. For these cases, of course, there is no problem because they are not living there. This flat is extra; they have sublet the whole flat to other people. So for these cases, there is no problem of hardship.

     Mr Jeyaretnam: Mr Speaker, Sir, I am obliged to the Minister. But he has only given us the figures for two categories. When I asked a question on the 31st of August 1982 for written answer, the reply I got was that there were 10 categories of persons who were debarred from applying for HDB flats. Does the Minister have the figures for persons who have been debarred under all these categories, category by category? Because I was given 10 categories on the 31st of August 1982.

     The Leader of the House (Mr S. Dhanabalan): Mr Speaker, Sir, on a point of order. Sir, I think we must stop this habit of the Member not starting on his speech on the motion and pretending to ask for clarifications for a long time and then saying, "Now, I am going to start and speak on the motion." He can raise all these questions during his speech and the Minister can answer them at the end.

     Mr Jeyaretnam: I would like the Minister to give me these figures before I speak.

     Mr Speaker: After you have spoken. It would save a lot of time if you speak first and the Minister will give you the figures later on.

Column: 335



     Mr Jeyaretnam: All right, Sir, if you so direct. May I say that Members are entitled to information, at least in this House ---

     Mr Dhanabalan: You will be given the information.

     Mr Jeyaretnam: --- if they wish to speak on any Bill. What is all the secrecy that this Government ---

     Mr Dhanabalan: You will get all the figures.

     Mr Jeyaretnam: Does the Leader of the House wish to say something?

     Mr Dhanabalan: You don't follow procedures.

     Mr Speaker: Do carry on, Mr Jeyaretnam.

     Mr Jeyaretnam: Mr Speaker, Sir, this Bill, may I say from the outset, is unprincipled in its entirety. It is obnoxious and it is discriminatory.

    Sir, after the last elections, the Prime Minister acknowledged that there was a message from the electorate - that they were sending a direct signal to the Government that the Government was getting very oppressive, making things very hard and that they wanted a relaxation of the rules and conditions under which they were tied down by the Government. Sometime after the general elections, maybe a month, two or three months after that, there was a report of a forum or gathering at which the First Deputy Prime Minister was present. And it was reported that he had agreed with somebody saying, "I think you have a point there" when the man complained about all the unnecessary measures and restrictions and the powers that the HDB appeared to enjoy. So one thought that perhaps the Government having received this clear signal, as the Prime Minister put it, from the electorate, would think a little bit and being an accountable Government that it is, accountable to the people, taking into account the people's wishes and their needs and their desires, it would try and examine all the powers exercised by statutory boards and the Government to see whether there was any area in which these powers could perhaps be reduced or

Column: 336

completely taken away. The Government says all this. But what do we find in action? We find that the Government has no such intention of relaxing any rules or conditions under which the people are tied down. On the contrary, it would appear that the Government proposes that statutory boards and itself should arm themselves with more powers so that the citizens may be further ground down, so that whatever rights they even now have may be taken away from them. This is the sort of double talk, talking with a forked tongue, that is so familiar of this Government and of which the people are now fully cognizant, and of which they are getting a little bit sick and tired.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, this Bill, I said, is obnoxious. It flouts well-known principles of law. It runs counter to all accepted codes of human relationship and conduct, and it is discriminatory.      The Minister of State for Communications and Information (Mr Wong Kan Seng): Mr Speaker, Sir, I beg to move, "That the Bill be now read a Second time."

    Sir, the purpose of this Bill is to restrict the sale or distribution of foreign publications which have been declared as having engaged in the domestic politics of Singapore.

    Newspapers and news magazines are an influential tool for shaping public opinion. Public opinion is shaped not only by the way the editors and journalists comment on current issues but also by the very selection of headlines, pictures and features and the manner of their presentation. Because of the potent influence it can wield, the press must ensure that it exercises its influence in a responsible manner. A responsible press is crucial to nation building.

    Our local newspapers know that Singapore's multi-racial and multi-religious society is small and vulnerable. They are extremely careful about not causing any offence to any racial, religious or linguistic group. They need to have a keen sense of our security and economic circumstances in the Southeast Asian and global context. They know what would undermine Singapore's prosperity and long-term survival. Their ownership, management and editorial control therefore have to be in the hands of Singaporeans. This must be the case because those who have made this country their home will better appreciate the responsibility they have to exercise. Foreigners, whose roots are not in Singapore, must not be allowed to control the local media. The Newspaper and Printing Presses Act (NPPA) passed in Parliament

Column: 370

on 27th March 1974 is meant to ensure this. So far, this Act has served its purpose well.

    When the NPPA was enacted, it was not made applicable to foreign newspapers and news magazines whose ownership, management and editorial control are outside the jurisdiction of Singapore. There were few foreign publications in circulation in Singapore at that time. Now, the number of foreign publications available in Singapore has increased to 3,700. Some foreign newspapers and news magazines - eg. the Asian Wall Street Journal, International Herald Tribune, USA Today, Time and Economist - are printed in Singapore now. But they are still deemed to be foreign publications under this amendment Bill because their ownership, management and editorial control are outside Singapore.

    Also, 12 years ago, foreign newspapers and news magazines, especially those which commented on Singapore issues, did not have a significant circulation here. Since 1974, the sales in Singapore of foreign publications have increased. The total circulation of some of the major dailies and weeklies like the Asiaweek, Far Eastern Economic Review, International Herald Tribune, Time, Asian Wall Street Journal and Newsweek, is about 59,000.

    For some of them, for example, the Asian Wall Street Journal, Far Eastern Economic Review and Asiaweek, their circulation in Singapore constitutes quite a large percentage of their total sales. Almost one in seven copies of these publications I have just mentioned is sold in Singapore. They are therefore dependent to a great extent on the Singapore market. They are almost like a local newspaper. There is therefore a strong profit motive for them to try to use issues to increase their circulation.

    The vast majority of the 3,700 foreign publications report on Singapore fairly and objectively if and when they do so. They do not indulge in campaigns to influence Singaporean opinion.

    But there has been a tendency on the part of a few foreign publications, a very small minority, which try to stir up Singa-

Column: 371

porean feelings on local issues, even on sensitive issues like race and religion. I am not talking about these publications writing one or two unbalanced reports. They may have published these reports based on some incomplete information from which mistaken beliefs and conclusions were formed. We would overlook this if the mistake was genuine. But if the foreign publications resort to a pattern of reporting which seeks to distort the truth on local issues and to arouse the feelings of our people, then it is a different matter.

    When such foreign publications keep on publishing for a period of time, reports on local issues which are slanted, distorted or partisan, or when they try to influence our people on matters which they have no business to be involved in, or when they cast aspersions on our established institutions, then they are engaging in campaigns to influence local public opinion. They are considered to have stepped out of the bound of professional journalism into the realm of local politics. They will be considered as engaging in our domestic politics.

    Let me elaborate on what I mean. If over a period of time, a foreign publication carries a series of articles and letters on race and religion and attempts to influence people's opinion that a particular race has been discriminated against; two, when in its reporting of our key institutions, eg. our courts, it tries to cast doubts in the minds of our people that our courts are not independent and it maligns the integrity of our judiciary; and three, it imposes its own ideas of press freedom without the understanding of the nature of our society: all these constitute interference in our domestic politics.

    What I have given are just some examples. It is not necessary or practical for me to list all the situations under which a foreign publication is considered as having transgressed because the nature of topical and controversial issues will vary from time to time. We cannot allow our domestic political process to be influenced or guided by some foreign publications which have no stake in Singapore. If the foreign publications do these things, then they are meddling in our domestic politics.

    Some people said that this amendment is unnecessary. They said that the way to deal with these foreign publications which meddle with our domestic politics is to use the existing laws - like the Undesirable Publications Act, the Sedition Act, the Internal Security Act and the Penal Code. Let there be no delusion that the Government will hesitate to use the appropriate laws to deal with foreign publications when the situation demands. For example, late last year, the Asian Wall Street Journal and its editors were cited for contempt of our courts and were found guilty.

    But there is a Chinese saying:( ) sha ji he bi yong niu dao which means "there is no need to use a cow's knife to kill a chicken." The English version is: "There is no need to use a sledgehammer to kill a fly." Therefore, while there are existing laws which can deal with the problem of foreign press interference in Singapore's politics, they may not be the most appropriate tool.

    Let me give an example. If the Undesirable Publications Act were invoked and the foreign publication banned, then Singaporeans will not have the opportunity to read what is written about us. There will be no free flow of ideas which we all agree is necessary to develop Singapore into an international information centre. The advocates of the use of the Undesirable Publications Act have contradicted themselves when they urged the Government to ban the publications which meddle in our domestic politics and yet at the same time agreed with the Government that there should be free flow of ideas.

    Sir, what is at issue here is not freedom of information or free flow of ideas. There is no intention to curb the flow of information or ideas by banning the publications. A ban will be misrepresented by such publications and opportunists as fear of exposing our people to their reporting. We have no such fears. There is no intention whatsoever to deprive Singaporeans' access to information and views in foreign publications.

    We know that it is not possible to seal Singapore off completely from external influences in this age of the computer and

Column: 373

satellite technology. Singapore is a very open society. Singaporeans are affluent enough and they travel and read widely. They are free to read even foreign publications gazetted under the proposed amendments for we believe too that they are discerning enough. In fact, exposure to such foreign publications will enable Singaporeans to see for themselves the motive behind the reporting which seeks to manipulate them on local politics. It will be educational and will contribute to a more resilient nation through a better understanding of the ways of the world.

    So the issue is not freedom of information or free flow of ideas. Let us not be befuddled or fooled by proponents of this view. The issue before us is: how do we stop such publications from profiting financially by consistently attempting to manipulate local opinion and interfering in our domestic politics under the guise of freedom of the press. The Bill is the answer.

    Advocates of freedom of the press feel that the press, especially the foreign press, should be completely free to do and say as they please. But we all know that to secure freedom there is a price, there is a cost to be paid. Our freedom to walk on our streets without harrassment of criminals, for example, is paid for by the money we spent in maintaining law and order. Our freedom to breathe clean air, for example, is paid for by the money we spent to prevent environmental pollution.

    If absolute freedom is exercised by the foreign press in Singapore and if they are allowed to interfere with our domestic political process, manipulate local opinion by slanted and divisive reporting, then the price we pay will be chaos and confusion and this will lead to instability and strife. Column: 374

reduction in circulation will affect advertising revenue and hence profits. That is why foreign publications are worried. If this were not the case, then they would have no cause for alarm.

They represent 65 news agencies, news magazines, newspapers and broadcasting stations. They are free to report on Singapore. But we expect them to report events, government decisions and policies objectively and accurately and not to resort to distortions just because they do not agree with us.

    Sir, let me now touch on the main features of this Bill. Under section 18A(1), the Minister will be empowered, by order published in the Gazette, to declare a foreign publication as engaging in the domestic politics of Singapore. The Minister will exercise this power reasonably and in good faith and on proper grounds. The declaration of a foreign publication is not a matter to be entered into lightly. There need not be any fear that the Minister is given such a discretion to act.

    The sale or distribution in Singapore of a foreign publication so declared will be restricted to a specified number of copies under section 18A(4). A person found with more than five unauthorized copies will be deemed to have possessed them for sale or distribution under section 18A(6). Reproduction for sale or distribution will be an offence under section 18B. Copies that are allowed in can be freely circulated or passed around.

    Sections 18C and D deal with persons or parcels that come into Singapore. The sections allow the appropriate authorities to search, detain and dispose of declared publications found in the person or parcel. To ensure that the restriction in number of copies is effective, subscription to foreign publications, except through an authorized dealer, is prohibited under section 18E.
